title: How many moles of H₂O can be formed from 3.54 × 10²³ molecules of NH₃ from the following equation? 4 NH₃(g) + 5 O₂(g) → 4 NO(g) + 6 H₂O(g) - Quora

response.answer_text: Balanced equation 4NH₃(g) + 5O₂(g) --> 4NO(g) + 6H₂O(g) Calculate the moles of NH₃ in 3.54 × 10²³ molecules. 1 mole of molecules = 6.022 × 10²³ molecules 3.54 × 10²³ NH₃ molecules × 1 mol NH₃ molecules/6.022 × 10²³ NH₃ molecules = 0.5878 mol NH₃ molecules Use stoichiometry to calculate the moles of H₂O that can be produced by 0.5878 mol NH₃ molecules, using the mole ratio between H₂O and NH₃ in the balanced equation. 0.5878 mol NH₃ × 6 mol H₂O/4 mol NH₃ = 0.882 mol H₂O to three significant figures 3.54 × 10²³ molecules of ammonia, when reacted with excess oxygen, can produce ≈ 0.882 mol water.
